sen.j: 徳川 昭武（とくがわ あきたけ）は、清水徳川家第6代当主、のち水戸藩最後（第11代）の藩主。
sen.e: Akitake TOKUGAWA was the sixth family head of the Shimizu Tokugawa family and later became the last (the 11th) lord of the Mito domain.
Akitake TOKUGAWA was the sixth family head of the Shimizu Tokugawa family and later became the last (the 11th) lord of the Mito domain.
Akitake TOKUGAWA was the sixth family head of the Shimizu Tokugawa family and later became the last (the 11th) lord of the Mito domain.

sen.j: 第9代藩主徳川斉昭の18男、第15代征夷大将軍徳川慶喜の異母弟にあたる。
sen.e: He was the 18th son of Nariaki TOKUGAWA, the ninth lord of domain and younger paternal half-brother of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the 15th seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").

He was the 18th son of Nariaki TOKUGAWA, the ninth lord of domain and younger paternal half-brother of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the 15th seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").

He was the 18th son of Nariaki TOKUGAWA, the ninth lord of domain and younger paternal half-brother of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, the 15th seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").

sen.j: 生母は側室・万里小路建房の6女睦子（ちかこ）。
sen.e: His mother was Nariaki's concubine Chikako, the sixth daughter of Tatefusa MADENOKOJI.
His mother was Nariaki's concubine Chikako, the sixth daughter of Tatefusa MADENOKOJI.
His mother was Nariaki's concubine Chikako, the sixth daughter of Tatefusa MADENOKOJI.

sen.j: 初名を松平昭徳。
sen.e: He was first named Akinori MATSUDAIRA.
He was first named Akinori MATSUDAIRA.
He was first named Akinori MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 字は子明。
sen.e: His azana (adult males nickname) was Shimei.
His azana (adult males nickname) was Shimei.
His azana (adult males nickname) was Shimei.

sen.j: 号 (称号)はらん山。
sen.e: His pseudonym (title) was Ranzan.
His pseudonym (title) was Ranzan.
His pseudonym (title) was Ranzan.

sen.j: 諡は節公。
sen.e: His shi (a posthumous name) was Sekko.
His shi (a posthumous name) was Sekko.
His shi (a posthumous name) was Sekko.

sen.j: 正室は中院通富の娘。
sen.e: His lawful wife was the daughter of Michitomi NAKANOIN.
His lawful wife was a daughter of Michitomi NAKANOIN.
sen.cmt: the daughter of --> a daughter of
sen.e: His lawful wife was a daughter of Michitomi NAKANOIN.

sen.j: 子は徳川武定（次男）など。
sen.e: One of his children was Takesada TOKUGAWA (the second son).
One of his children was Takesada TOKUGAWA (the second son).
One of his children was Takesada TOKUGAWA (the second son).

sen.j: 正仁親王妃華子の曽祖父。
sen.e: He was the great-grandfather of Princess Hanako, the wife of Imperial Prince Masahito.
He was the great-grandfather of Princess Hanako, the wife of Imperial Prince Masahito.
He was the great-grandfather of Princess Hanako, the wife of Imperial Prince Masahito.

sen.j: 嘉永6年（1853年）、江戸駒込の水戸藩江戸藩邸で誕生。
sen.e: He was born in edohantei (residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) in Komagome, the Mito domain in 1853.
He was born in 1853 in edohantei (a residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) of the Mito Domain in Komagome.
He was born in 1853 in edohantei (a residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) of the Mito Domain in Komagome.

sen.j: 幼名は余八麿。
sen.e: His childhood name was Yohachimaro.
His childhood name was Yohachimaro.
His childhood name was Yohachimaro.

sen.j: その半年後から水戸にて養育されるが、幕末の動乱のため、文久3年（1863年）には再度江戸入り。
sen.e: He was raised in Mito since six months after his birth, but he re-entered Edo due to the bakufu's disturbance in 1863.
He had been raised in Mito since six months after his birth, but he re-entered Edo due to the bakufu's disturbance in 1863.
He had been raised in Mito since six months after his birth, but he re-entered Edo due to the bakufu's disturbance in 1863.

sen.j: 同年、京都で病に伏した兄昭訓の看護の名目により上京。
sen.e: In the same year, he went up to Kyoto to nurse his older brother Akikuni who became ill in Kyoto.
In the same year, he went up to Kyoto to nurse his older brother Akikuni who became ill in Kyoto.
In the same year, he went up to Kyoto to nurse his older brother Akikuni who became ill in Kyoto.

sen.j: 当初は長者町の藩邸に滞在するが、禁門の変の後は東大谷長楽寺、本圀寺に滞在する（これにより滞京中の水戸藩士は本圀寺勢と称される）。
sen.e: He stayed in the residence in Choja-machi at first, but he stayed in Choraku-ji Temple in Higashi Otani and Honkoku-ji Temple after Kinmon Incident (this was why feudal retainers of the Mito Domain staying in Kyoto was called Honkoku-ji Temple force).

He stayed in the residence in Choja-machi at first, but he stayed in Choraku-ji Temple in Higashi Otani and Honkoku-ji Temple after Kinmon Incident (this was why feudal retainers of the Mito Domain staying in Kyoto were called Honkoku-ji Temple force).

He stayed in the residence in Choja-machi at first, but he stayed in Choraku-ji Temple in Higashi Otani and Honkoku-ji Temple after Kinmon Incident (this was why feudal retainers of the Mito Domain staying in Kyoto were called Honkoku-ji Temple force).

sen.j: 滞京中の佐幕活動は多忙を極め、禁門の変や天狗党の動乱に際しては一軍の将として出陣するなど、幼年ながらも幕末の動乱に参加している。
sen.e: He was extremely busy on supporting activities for the bakufu while in Kyoto and attended the disturbance in the end of Edo period although he was still young by departing as the leader of the army at the time of Kinmon Incident and Tengu Party's Disturbance.

He was extremely busy supporting activities for the bakufu during the stay in Kyoto and participated in disturbances in the end of Edo period, such as Kinmon Incident and Tengu Party's Disturbance, as a leader of the army although he was still young at the time.

He was extremely busy supporting activities for the bakufu during the stay in Kyoto and participated in disturbances in the end of Edo period, such as Kinmon Incident and Tengu Party's Disturbance, as a leader of the army although he was still young at the time.

sen.j: 従五位侍従兼民部大輔に叙任。
sen.e: He was appointed to Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank), jiju (a chamberlain) and Minbu taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Popular Affairs).
He was appointed to Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank), jiju (a chamberlain) and Minbu taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Popular Affairs).
He was appointed to Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank), jiju (a chamberlain) and Minbu taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of Popular Affairs).

sen.j: 第14代将軍徳川家茂の死去に伴い、諱を昭武と改名。
sen.e: Due to the death of Iemochi TOKUGAWA, the fourteenth Shogun, he changed his imina (personal name) to Akitake.
Due to the death of Iemochi TOKUGAWA, the fourteenth Shogun, he changed his imina (personal name) to Akitake.
Due to the death of Iemochi TOKUGAWA, the fourteenth Shogun, he changed his imina (personal name) to Akitake.

sen.j: 慶応2年（1867年）、清水徳川家を相続。
sen.e: He succeeded to the Shimizu Tokugawa family in 1867.
He succeeded to the Shimizu Tokugawa family in 1867.
He succeeded to the Shimizu Tokugawa family in 1867.

sen.j: 同時にパリ万国博覧会 (1867年)に将軍慶喜の名代としてヨーロッパ派遣を命じられる。
sen.e: At the same time, he was dispatched to Europe as the representative of the Shogun Yoshinobu to attend Paris Exposition (1867).
At the same time, he was dispatched to Europe as the representative of the Shogun Yoshinobu to attend Paris Exposition (1867).
At the same time, he was dispatched to Europe as the representative of the Shogun Yoshinobu to attend Paris Exposition (1867).

sen.j: 万博終了後に引き続き、幕府代表としてスイス、ベルギー、オランダ、イギリス、イタリアなど欧州各国を歴訪。
sen.e: After Paris Exposition, he visited Switzerland, Bergium, Netherlands, England, and Italy as the representative of the bakufu.
After Paris Exposition, he visited Switzerland, Belgium, Netherlands, the United Kingdom, and Italy as the representative of the bakufu.
sen.cmt: Bergium --> Belgium, England --> the United kingdom
sen.e: After Paris Exposition, he visited Switzerland, Belgium, Netherlands, the United Kingdom, and Italy as the representative of the bakufu.

sen.j: 以後はパリにて留学生活を送る。
sen.e: He studied in Paris afterward.
He studied in Paris afterward.
He studied in Paris afterward.

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）、新政府からの帰国命令を受けて帰国する。
sen.e: In 1868, he was ordered to return home from the new government, so he departed for home.
In 1868, he was ordered to return home from the new government, so he departed for home.
In 1868, he was ordered to return home from the new government, so he departed for home.

sen.j: 翌年には水戸徳川家を相続し、最後の水戸藩主に就任した。
sen.e: In 1869, he succeeded to the Mito Tokugawa family and was appointed to the last lord of the Mito domain.
In 1869, he succeeded to the Mito Tokugawa family and was appointed to the last lord of the Mito domain.
In 1869, he succeeded to the Mito Tokugawa family and was appointed to the last lord of the Mito domain.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）、版籍奉還により水戸藩知藩事（民部大輔を辞官）。
sen.e: In 1869, he resigned Chihanji (Minbu taifu) of the Mito domain due to Hanseki-hokan (return of lands and people to the emperor).
In 1869, he resigned Chihanji (Minbu taifu) of the Mito domain due to Hanseki-hokan (return of lands and people to the emperor).
In 1869, he resigned Chihanji (Minbu taifu) of the Mito domain due to Hanseki-hokan (return of lands and people to the emperor).

sen.j: 昭武は北海道の土地割渡しを出願し、明治2年（1869年）8月17日北海道天塩国のうち苫前郡、天塩郡、上川郡 (天塩国)、中川郡 (天塩国)と、北見国のうち利尻郡の計5郡の支配を命じられた。
sen.e: Akitake requested to have the divided lands of Hokkaido and was ordered to dominate five counties in total, such as Tomakomae County, Teshio County, Kamikawa County, and Nakagawa County out of Teshio Province, Hokkaido, and Rishiri County out of Kitami Province on September 22, 1869.

Akitake applied to have the divided lands of Hokkaido and was ordered to dominate five counties in total, such as Tomakomae County, Teshio County, Kamikawa County, and Nakagawa County out of Teshio Province, Hokkaido, and Rishiri County out of Kitami Province on September 22, 1869.
sen.cmt: requested to have --> applied to have
sen.e: Akitake applied to have the divided lands of Hokkaido and was ordered to dominate five counties in total, such as Tomakomae County, Teshio County, Kamikawa County, and Nakagawa County out of Teshio Province, Hokkaido, and Rishiri County out of Kitami Province on September 22, 1869.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）7月14日の廃藩置県により藩知事を免ぜられ、東京府向島の小梅邸（旧水戸藩下屋敷）に暮らす。
sen.e: He was appointed to the governor of domain due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) on August 29, 1871 and lived in the residence of Koume (former residence of Mito domain) in Mukojima, Tokyo Prefecture.

He was appointed to the governor of domain due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) on August 29, 1871 and lived in the residence of Koume (former residence of Mito domain) in Mukojima, Tokyo Prefecture.

He was appointed to the governor of domain due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) on August 29, 1871 and lived in the residence of Koume (former residence of Mito domain) in Mukojima, Tokyo Prefecture.

sen.j: 明治7年（1875年）、少尉に任官。
sen.e: He was appointed to shojo (junior lieutenant) in 1875.
He was appointed to second lieutenant in 1875.
He was appointed to second lieutenant in 1875.

sen.j: 初期の陸軍戸山学校にて、教官として生徒隊に軍事教養を教授している。
sen.e: He taught military education to the students as the instructor at the initial Army Toyama School.
He gave military education to the students as an instructor at the initial Army Toyama School.
sen.cmt: taught を gaveに変更、instructorの冠詞をthe からaに変更
sen.e: He gave military education to the students as an instructor at the initial Army Toyama School.

sen.j: 明治9年（1876年）にアメリカ合衆国のフィラデルフィアで開催されるフィラデルフィア万国博覧会の御用掛となり訪米。
sen.e: In 1876, he became Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for Philadelphia Exposition held in Philadelphia, USA.
In 1876, he became Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for Philadelphia Exposition held in Philadelphia, USA.
In 1876, he became Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for Philadelphia Exposition held in Philadelphia, USA.

sen.j: その後、フィラデルフィアからパリに向かい再び留学する。
sen.e: He went to Paris to study again after Philadelphia Exposition.
He went to Paris to study again after Philadelphia Exposition.
He went to Paris to study again after Philadelphia Exposition.

sen.j: 明治13年（1881年）に帰国。
sen.e: He returned home in 1881.
He returned home in 1881.
He returned home in 1881.

sen.j: 明治16年（1883年）、甥篤敬に家督を譲り、翌年には戸定邸（松戸市）にて隠居した。
sen.e: He ceded the family head position to his nephew Atsuyoshi in 1883 and retired in the Tojo residence (in Matsudo City) next year.
He ceded the family head position to his nephew Atsuyoshi in 1883 and retired to live in the Tojo residence (in Matsudo City) next year.
sen.cmt: retired in the Tojo residence --> retired to live in the Tojo residence
sen.e: He ceded the family head position to his nephew Atsuyoshi in 1883 and retired to live in the Tojo residence (in Matsudo City) next year.

sen.j: 明治25年（1892年）、次男武定が子爵に叙されて松戸徳川家を創設している。
sen.e: In 1892, his second son Takesada was appointed to viscount and found the Matsudo Tokugawa family.
In 1892, his second son Takesada was appointed to viscount and founded the Matsudo Tokugawa family.
In 1892, his second son Takesada was appointed to viscount and founded the Matsudo Tokugawa family.
He died on July 3, 1910.
He died on July 3, 1910.
He died on July 3, 1910.

sen.j: 享年58
sen.e: He was 58 years old.
He was 58 years old.
He was 58 years old.

sen.j: ヨーロッパ派遣団一行の中には、渋沢栄一も名を連ねている。
sen.e: Eichi SHIBUSAWA was also one of the members of the European delegation.
Eichi SHIBUSAWA was also a member of the delegation to Europe.
Eichi SHIBUSAWA was also a member of the delegation to Europe.

sen.j: 斉昭の子息の内、写真が現存するは慶喜、昭武、慶徳、茂政のみである。
sen.e: Among Nariaki's sons, photos are extant only for Yoshinobu, Akitake, Yoshinori, and Mochimasa.
Among Nariaki's sons, photos are extant only for Yoshinobu, Akitake, Yoshinori, and Mochimasa.
Among Nariaki's sons, photos are extant only for Yoshinobu, Akitake, Yoshinori, and Mochimasa.

sen.j: 万国博覧会では諸国首脳と交流を深めたが、近世日本と欧州各国列強との交流の始まりと認められる。
sen.e: He enhanced exchanges with summits in various countries at the exposition, so it was recognized as the beginning of the exchanges between modern Japan and the powerful countries in Europe.

He had and deepened relationship with leaders from various countries at the exposition, which is considered to have been the beginning of the relationship between modern Japan and the powerful countries in Europe.

He had and deepened relationship with leaders from various countries at the exposition, which is considered to have been the beginning of the relationship between modern Japan and the powerful countries in Europe.

sen.j: 幕府によって作成が計画された勲章が「葵勲章」である。
sen.e: The medal that was projected to create by the bakufu was 'Aoi Kunsho' (Order of Mallow).
'Aoi Kunsho' (Order of Mallow) was a medal that the bakufu projected to create.
'Aoi Kunsho' (Order of Mallow) was a medal that the bakufu projected to create.

sen.j: 自転車や狩猟、写真などの多彩な趣味を有した。
sen.e: He had various hobbies such as a bicycle ride, hunting, and photo shoot.
He had various hobbies such as a bicycle ride, hunting, and photo shoot.
He had various hobbies such as a bicycle ride, hunting, and photo shoot.

sen.j: 隠居後は静岡市の慶喜との往来も盛んで、一緒に写真撮影や狩猟に出かけるなど交流を深めた。
sen.e: After the retirement, he frequently traveled to Yoshinobu in Shizuoka City and deepened the exchanges by taking photos and going for hunting together.
After the retirement, he frequently traveled to Yoshinobu in Shizuoka City and deepened the relationship through taking photos and going hunting together.
sen.cmt: the exchanges をthe relashionship に、by taking を through taking に、going on huntingを going huntingに変更
sen.e: After the retirement, he frequently traveled to Yoshinobu in Shizuoka City and deepened the relationship through taking photos and going hunting together.

sen.j: 写真撮影には熱心で、現在もなお多くの写真が残されている。
sen.e: He was enthusiastic about for photo shoot, so many photos are still extant.
He was enthusiastic about photo shoot, so that many photos are still extant.
sen.cmt: enthusiastic about for --> enthusiastic about, so --> so that
sen.e: He was enthusiastic about photo shoot, so that many photos are still extant.

sen.j: - 誕生。
sen.e: He was born.
He was born.

sen.j: - 上京して佐幕活動に従事。
sen.e: He went up to Kyoto and served for supporting activities for the bakufu.

sen.j: 従五位下侍従・民部大輔に任官。
sen.e: He was appointed to Jugoinoge, jiju and Minbu taifu.

sen.j: - 天狗党討伐に出陣。
sen.e: He departed for Tengu Party's subjugation.

sen.j: - 昭武と改名。
sen.e: He changed his name to Akitake.

sen.j: 清水徳川家を相続。
sen.e: He succeeded to the Shimizu Tokugawa family.

sen.j: 従四位下左近衛権少将。
sen.e: He became Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), Sakone gon no shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).
He became Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), Sakone gon no shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).
He became Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), Sakone gon no shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards).

sen.j: パリ万国博覧会 (1867年)に参加。
sen.e: He attended Paris Exposition (1867).
He attended Paris Exposition (1867).
He attended Paris Exposition (1867).

sen.j: これ以後、欧州各国を歴訪するなどフランスにて留学。
sen.e: He visited various countries in Europe and studied in France afterward.
He visited various countries in Europe and studied in France afterward.
He visited various countries in Europe and studied in France afterward.

sen.j: - フランスより帰国、水戸藩主に就任（水戸徳川家を相続）。
sen.e: He returned home from France and was appointed to the lord of Mito domain (he succeeded to the Mito Tokugawa family).
He returned home from France and was appointed to the lord of Mito domain (he succeeded to the Mito Tokugawa family).
He returned home from France and was appointed to the lord of Mito domain (he succeeded to the Mito Tokugawa family).

sen.j: 版籍奉還により水戸藩知事。
sen.e: He became the governor of Mito domain due to Hanseki-hokan.
He became the governor of Mito domain due to Hanseki-hokan.
He became the governor of Mito domain due to Hanseki-hokan.
He received Eiseiroku (premiums)(3,500 koku (crop fields)).

sen.j: 北海道開拓を巡見。
sen.e: He inspected Hokkaido development.
He inspected Hokkaido development.
He inspected Hokkaido development.

sen.j: - 廃藩置県。
sen.e: Haihan-chiken was enforced.
Haihan-chiken was enforced.

sen.j: 東京に移住。
sen.e: He moved to Tokyo.
He moved to Tokyo.
He moved to Tokyo.

sen.j: - 陸軍少尉任官。
sen.e: He was appointed to Army shojo.
He was appointed to second lieutenant of Japanese Army.

sen.j: - 陸軍戸山学校教官（生徒隊付）。
sen.e: He became the instructor at Army Toyama School (for students)

sen.j: - アメリカ万国博覧会御用掛としてアメリカへ派遣。
sen.e: He was dispatched to the United States as Goyogakari for the United States Exposition.
He was dispatched to the United States as Goyogakari for the United States Exposition.

sen.j: 陸軍少尉免官。
sen.e: He was discharged from the Army shojo.

sen.cmt: the Army shojo --> second lieutenant of Japanese Army

sen.j: - 従三位、麝香間祗候。
sen.e: He became Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in Jako room).
He became Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in Jako room).
He became Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and Jako no ma shiko (emperor's personal attendant in Jako room).

sen.j: - 大能牧場を復興。
sen.e: He restored Ono bokujo (pasture).
He restored Ono bokujo (pasture).
He restored Ono bokujo (pasture).

sen.j: 小梅邸行幸。
sen.e: Imperial visit to the Koume residence.
Imperial visit to the Koume residence.

sen.j: - 戸定邸に居住。
sen.e: He moved to Tojo residence.
He moved to Tojo residence.
He moved to Tojo residence.

sen.j: - 嗣子武定、子爵授爵（松戸徳川家の創設）。
sen.e: His heir Takesada was appointed to viscount (found the Matsudo Tokugawa family).
His heir Takesada was appointed to viscount (foundation of the Matsudo Tokugawa family).
His heir Takesada was appointed to viscount (foundation of the Matsudo Tokugawa family).

sen.j: - 水戸徳川家を後見。
sen.e: He acted as the guardian for the Mito Tokugawa family.
He acted as the guardian for the Mito Tokugawa family.
He acted as the guardian for the Mito Tokugawa family.

sen.j: - 死去。
sen.e: He died.
He died.

sen.j: 墓所：茨城県常陸太田市の瑞龍山。
sen.e: Grave: Mt. Zuiryu in Hitachi-ota City, Ibaraki Prefecture.
